awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Faunal Composition, Provinciality and Paleobiolgy of a Late Cretaceous Arctic Vertebrate Assemblage Revealed Through Cross-Latitudinal Comparisons
awd_abstract_narration:
The 70-million year old Prince Creek Formation of Arctic Alaska provides fossil evidence that a surprisingly diverse array of dinosaurs, birds, flying reptiles and small mammals lived in polar forests characterized by warm summers and five- to six-months of darkness and snowfall during the polar winter. Enduring these seasonally intense and variable conditions makes these animals uniquely suited to test major paleobiological questions pertaining to physiology, migration, body size changes, ecology and distribution. This project will examine these questions through new Arctic specimen collections and identifications, temperature determinations and growth studies, and comparison to findings with animals living at warmer lower latitudes. This project will bring together a diverse team of scientists who will share new ideas and methodologies and contribute to the education and training of graduate and undergraduate students. Results will be disseminated in scientific venues and presented publicly through museum exhibitions and K-12 presentations. The latter will include visits to rural, northern Alaskan schools to provide underserved Alaska Native students and teachers with an opportunity to learn about the fossils in their area and interact with NSF-sponsored researchers. 

Using macro- and microfossil remains, this study will establish a comprehensive dataset on the faunal composition of a Mesozoic polar assemblage, including descriptions of probable new species unique to the Arctic. Statistical techniques will be used to compare the faunal compositions between mid- and high latitudes to understand North American distribution patterns. Histological analyses of bones and teeth will provide the first rigorous testing of the affects of polar environments on the growth and physiology of dinosaurs and mammals. Lastly, a novel technique using biomarkers will be used to provide more precise paleotemperature estimates to understand the temperature regime experienced by the polar fauna.

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: THE REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF COLORADO

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
The primary goals of this collaborative project are to characterize, describe, and provide insight into the paleobiology of the Late Cretaceous (ca. 70 Mya) vertebrate fauna that inhabited Alaska?s North Slope - the northernmost land mass at this time (80 - 85?N paleolat), and estimate paleotemperature and other aspects of the climate by analyzing organic geochemical residues produced by ancient soil bacteria. PI Eberle's research concentrates on the fossil mammals of northern Alaska's Prince Creek Formation, where at least one metatherian (or marsupial), three eutherians (or placental mammals), and three kinds of multituberculate mammal are represented by tiny teeth and jaws. Co-PI Sepulveda's research focuses on estimating the paleotemperature as well as the paleohydrology (by way of measuring the hydrogen isotopic composition of plant waxes) during the Late Cretaceous in northern Alaska.

We described the first metatherian from the North Slope, a tiny opossum-like mammal named Unnuakomys hutchisoni (literally means 'Hutchison's night mouse') that represents the northernmost known metatherian (or marsupial) in the world; this research was published in 2019 in the Journal of Systematic Palaeontology. Eberle and her team of students also recovered hundreds of tiny fossil bones and teeth by sorting (under a microscope) more than 100 lbs of sedimentary matrix from the Prince Creek Formation collected from the North Slope. We continue to study the tiny (~1 mm long) mammal teeth, including of a new tiny insectivorous mammal that lived year-round on the North Slope as well as the teeth of multituberculate mammals, an extinct group with teeth characterized by rows of many cusps (or tubercles). 

We also estimated the mean annual air temperature for the North Slope of Alaska to be approximately 8 degrees C during Late Cretaceous time. 

With regard to greater impacts, Eberle presented her research on Late Cretaceous Alaskan mammals at two Society of Vertebrate Paleontology Annual Meetings (2017, 2020), and she was first author on a paper in the Journal of Systematic Palaeontology (Eberle et al. 2019) that described the first metatherian (marsupial) from the North Slope. Eight CU-Boulder students - four undergraduates and four graduate students, three of whom are from diverse backgrounds - participated on this project. The students gained hands-on experience in washing and sorting sedimentary matrix in search of tiny vertebrate fossils, identifying a diversity of fossil bones and teeth (e.g., dinosaurs, fish, mammals), and cataloguing the fossils. Additionally, a postdoctoral researcher and a lab assistant participated in Sepulveda's research on estimating the Late Cretaceous paleoclimate of the North Slope. Eberle presented her research at an Arctic Fossil Family Day in Nov 2019 that saw over 300 visitors to the CU Museum of Natural History. She also participated in several sessions of the Girls At the Museum Exploring Science (GAMES) afterschool program at the CU Museum. The GAMES Program's goal is to increase scientific literacy and interest in 4th and 5th grade girls from low-socioeconomic and diverse backgrounds.

 


Last Modified: 12/28/2022
Modified by: Jaelyn J Eberle
